p: The influence of EIP on DENV epidemiology was recently examined in the context of Wolbachia-mediated blocking of virus transmission [ 21, 22]. Earlier studies suggested that viral genetic variation in EIP could also influence DENV epidemiology in nature. For example, differences of EIP among DENV type 2 strains have been proposed as a mechanism of genotype replacement and dengue emergence [ 23]. By comparing three DENV type 2 strains of the American genotype with three DENV type 2 strain of the Southeast Asian genotype, Anderson and Rico-Hesse estimated a 2- to 65-fold increase in vectorial capacity for the invasive Southeast Asian genotype relative to the resident American genotype [ 23]. This increase resulted from a 7-day difference in EIP between genotypes (7 days for the Southeast Asian vs. 14 days for the American genotype) across a range of daily survival rates. However, EIP was estimated as a single ‘threshold’ value defined as the time at which 50% of salivary glands became infected, which likely misrepresents EIP for an entire population [ 24].
